comments.commentBody: Keep up the good work, Kevin!!!!!!

I served on the disbursement board of ACSTO.  The ten percent overhead is very low in comparison to other 501c3.  Groups.  Our charter was simple.  To get the funds that  the most students in need.  Mr.  Yarborough,  was not the decision maker.  Our committee was.  This report lacks all the facts.  Respectfully.
Well then why in the heck were you paying him $125,000 per year to be the "executive director". Seems like your statement is missing some facts.
It's still a conflict of interest.
Another great example of political corruption.  The ACSTO board and Mr. Yarborough should be held legally accountable for cheating the taxpayers of Arizona. This is bribery plain and simple.
Unfortunately it is well known, and his district and the other powers that be in AZ don't seem to care.  For the rest of us, maddening and frustrating.
Smart ones.
Why are such corrupt politicians in office? Who votes for these money oriented crooks?  Let's have some clear divisions between what you can and cannot do, own or be while in office of this country.
Yarborough is not an 'advocate"; he is an elected official who is profiteering in a big way.  That's as bad as any of the rest of it.
The "rigorous oversight" is the part that's usually left out!
That's both the game plan and the goal !  Public tax dollars morphed into private profits at the expense of schools and children.  Isn't AZ the bottom of the education barrel?

Frank -

Thank you for this! Made my day. I cooked some trout tonight with wine, shallots and capers, but I would have equally have loved a hunk of meat loaf with, yes, Heinz ketchup on top. Trump has many flaws. Please let us concentrate on the ones that matter!

Yes, Arizona does need to drain its own swamp, as one commenter stated. It's a big swamp. Last year, voters passed Proposition 123--a nasty law designed to take money from the state's Land Trust to bolster the public school systems. A lot of people who wanted to see the schools receive more money held their noses and voted yes despite the certainty that the land trust would be raided. This money was to go to teacher salaries which are far below the national average. We are hemorrhaging teachers: 40 or 50% leave after just two years in the classrooms.

Recently Governor Ducey proudly announced his plan for teachers' raises: a 4% raise over the next 5 years. Wow! Don't knock yourself out. I don't know how he wasn't embarrassed to make that announcement. Ducey is huge supported of charter schools--he often surrounds himself with charter school owners.

Yesterday, my daughter, who is a teacher, received next year's contract from the Creighton school district. NO raise "pending legislation." NONE. Meanwhile, she works in classrooms with broken windows and roaches, dead and alive. She buys $650 of supplies per year (with my help) because students are so poor. This includes boxes of granola bars they hand out to the kids on Fridays in case they have nothing else to eat over the weekend.

How does Steve Yarbrough sleep at night when he's making 100s of thousands of dollars per year and my daughter is making 38K working long, long hours and teaching 35 deserving kids.

The greedy don't care.
Low teacher pay that creates constant teacher turnover is one way they worsen the public system so parents are forced to "choose" charters. Letting existing facilities rot is another way.

Once at charters, parents and kids quickly figure out they're just storefronts, but by then the greedy charter operators have gotten their cash.

We need legislation that caps the total compensation of anyone who receives even $1 of taxpayer money. Set a teacher salary (say $50K), let principals make $70K, let anyone the principal reports to, including the CEO or superintendent, only make double what teachers make. All money left over goes to hiring more teachers. Problem solved.

So why keep voting in Republicans? Republicans like to talk about lowering taxes, but when they do, they lower the taxes for the wealthy and the cuts made for the middleclass and below are paltry. Republicans like to talk about 'responsible' government, but when they govern they tend to plunder as much as they can while destroying the parts of government that really look out for the people. Democrats have gone along with far too much of this in the last 40 years, too, but then, they're trying to work with Republicans who have been pulling the USA toward a right wing dictatorship for decades now. Start voting in Democrats and pressure them to serve the people and you'll see a change for the better. But if Americans don't support more progressive voices and choices, you have no one to blame but yourselves.

All schools eligible for vouchers must be non-profit.

To ensure full access to private schools, laws must prevent them from refusing/removing students for illegitimate/bogus reasons.

Republican voucher plans unilaterally favoring private schools will spur negative side-effects, including:
• giving our taxes, in the guise of "education", to fund religions, white-supremacists, political organizations, special interest groups, sexist groups... anyone wanting government money to promote their cause WHILE indoctrinating children.
• creating a government bureaucracy to oversee the standards of many many schools. This powerful bureaucracy would be corruptible -- as Yarbrough has shown.
• use of private school fees to exclude groups. Fees must be based on parental income.
• profit/self-interest motives. They will put less quality resources into teaching/students, and will transfer funds to benefit themselves (profits, religious tithes).
• easy manipulation of student performance data, by refusing/removing "poor performing" students. This filtration will artificially raise metrics of private schools WHILE worsening those of competing (public) schools where those excluded students end up at. They will create fuzzy analytical data to give an appearance of high student performance.
• creating education Oligopolies.

Scandinavian public schools are a model we can emulate. They do not allow private schools, and so for 40 years have been the best in the world.

For corrupt politicians and their cronies, Not-For-Profit status of schools merely complicates the accounting  process of graft.  Given a complicit board, it is still possible to mis-spend funds for inappropriate administrative salaries; over-priced books, supplies and all manner of services; and leases from wholly owned for-profit LLCs. And every bit of this deceitful behavior is implicitly endorsed as acceptable practice by how it has been proudly modeled by the Kleptocrat-in-Chief and members of his Cabinet.
If private schools are getting tax vouchers, they should be required to admit and provide services to students with disabilities, including learning disabilities.

The Catholic schools in my area are not only integrated fully, but many operate in minority neighborhoods -- often offering the only quality education available for very poor minority children who have been cheated and failed by the public union-run local school district.

My sense is that Donald Trump and his yahoos (dining with him at taxpayer expense at his lavish private club in Florida which costs $3 Million per weekend trip) don't understand North Korea and "matters that are foreign" so North Korea is not a big concern to them.  For Donald Trump, all is okay as long as Kim Jong-un doesn't mess with Trump hotel properties. Folks, I fear the "Titanic" may be listing under the new Administration.

Ken, The US only has about 25-30,000 troops in South Korea.  China has over 2,000,000 on active duty and another over-2,000,000 on active reserve.  Kim Jong-un would laugh pretty hard if he heard that our 28,000 were there to "threaten" him.

You seem like a thoughtful person, but weakening our military presence in East Asia is not something that would comfort most Koreans and Korean-Americans. China has an expansionary foreign policy - similar to our Monroe Doctrine, they view the entire region of East Asia (from Malaysia to Manchuria) as their sphere of influence. One can somewhat understand their position, given their status as one of the dominant civilizations in human history.

That said, the explicit guarantee of US military protection of its Korean and Japanese allies is an important counterweight against the Chinese hegemon. Koreans are well-aware that much of their 4,000 yr history was spent fending off aggression from their larger, more powerful Chinese (and Japanese) neighbors.
Den, You mean there's a difference between a twitter war and a real one?
Crazy like a Fox?  Or an Inspector Clouseau clone?  Clouseau clone.

Rational concessions on the nuclear issue may be possible even from the insecure North Korea provided we and the South Koreans, the infinitely stronger side by any measure, offer certain concessions to the North: a peace treaty, diplomatic recognition, and a mutual non-aggression pact.

The U.S. should, of course, firmly insist on the condition that our defense treaty with, and military bases in, the South will remain in tact, and any further progress toward better relations with North Korea will depend on how Pyongyang holds its end of the bargain.

If we could open up relations with an extremely hostile China back in the early 1970s , I don't see why we can't do so with N.K.(and Iran as well) with some some carefully crafted bold moves.

Those who want to continue and deepen the present harsh confrontation with N.K on security or human-rights grounds will need to be persuaded that both can be ensured better by a life-affirming deal with Pyongyang . Calling all such moves with the knee-jerk label of appeasement achieves nothing positive at all and only increases the worst possible consequences.

Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter both have personally visited Pyongyang in the past to defuse situations on the brink. I don't know about Clinton now , but President Carter still may have enjoy some trust in North Korea. It certainly wouldn't hurt to deploy his good offices one more time. The question is: Will the Trump White House be bold enough to trust Carter?
Appeasement.

Impeach please?  Be careful what you wish for.  Mike Pence is every bit as bad as Trump in terms of ideology and policy; he's just not obviously crazy.  At least all eyes are on Trump and will remain there, whereas if Pence becomes POTUS, many eyes will turn away.

"Most here would believe the North."
Why would you say, or think, such a thing?
No one.  No one knew.

There is no point in trying to reason with the so-called "pro-life" (anti-abortion) movement. They are the Christian Taliban; intolerant of facts that contradict their Christian mythology and indifferent to the suffering their stiff-necked dogmatism may cause the most innocent among us. They're not pro-life...anything but.
Their minds won't be changed. But beating up their congressional co-conspirators with demands for a fact-based rather than faith-based rationale for their public policy stance may. No congressional seat is so safe that newspaper ads (it's called free speech and the newspaper that turns down the ads may be accused of stifling First Amendment freedoms) in their districts won't stir the embers of dissent and fuel demands for dollars and sense justifications for enabling unplanned pregnancy to burden the lives of mothers and children alike.

Richard, you spend half your time arguing that the trump you pretend not to like is, nevertheless, the right tool to rip everything apart because other politicians of the established parties are unable to do so, and the other half maintaining that he will do no such thing.

And today you did it in a single comment.

BTW, I would be careful about using the words "balance" and "trump" in the same sentence. First, balance (or anything else for the matter) is not something to be "imposed" in a western democracy, but that is trump's MO. Secondly, if you want balance in our nation, you won't get it from an unbalanced leader. In his (shady) business career he has been used to getting his own way, all the time. Now, for the first time, he is learning that running a country means accounting to others, and he is not taking kindly to it. According to reports on CNN, he is in a foul mood this weekend because of the Sessions/Russia affair and he's going around taking it out on his staff and blaming everyone but himself. Leaks happen but, having seen 14 presidencies, I don't remember ever hearing of a White House leak like of this nature. If as many instant pundits claimed he suddenly became “presidential” when he gave his speech to Congress, it certainly didn’t last long.

Not sure why, but this story appeared in Korean on my Yahoo start page. Very odd, and a little disconcerting. In this age of hacking, I was not sure if it was safe to click on the story! After copying and pasting into Google translate, it was obviously the same story. Weird...
On the same token Putin said if his back was against the wall he would not hesitate a first strike against us. So, are all leaders, even our own, maniacally power crazy?
